iti91:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti91:2.1.eng: “This is the last of lifestyles, mendicants, namely relying on alms.
iti91:2.1.comm: The unusual use of anta here is, I believe, a play on words. Per the commentary, it suggests the “least” of lifestyles, but it is also that which “makes an end” of suffering and future lives, as said just a few sentences below.

iti91:2.2.eng: The world curses you: ‘You beggar, walking bowl in hand!’

iti91:2.3.pli: Tañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, kulaputtā upenti atthavasikā, atthavasaṃ paṭicca;
iti91:2.3.eng: Yet earnest gentlemen take it up for a good reason.

iti91:2.4.pli: neva rājābhinītā, na corābhinītā, na iṇaṭṭā, na bhayaṭṭā, na ājīvikāpakatā.
iti91:2.4.eng: Not to escape a summons by a king or a summons for a bandit, or because you were in debt or in fear, or in order to make a living.
iti91:2.4.comm: The terms here follow the same sequence as in the Vinaya account of ordination. Generally, ordination should not be given in such cases, but if it is given, those performing it incur an offense of wrong-doing. | Soldiers joined the Sangha to escape military service, so the Buddha said one should not ordain those in service to a king (Kd 1:40.1.1). | Several rules regarding ordination of criminals were passed, the thrust of which is that wanted outlaws should not be ordained (Kd 1:41.1.1). | Another man ordained to escape debt (Kd 1:46.1.1). | Seventeen boys ordained as novices to get a nice livelihood (Kd 1:49.1.1). | The only item that does not straightforwardly correspond is “in fear” (bhayaṭṭa). In the Vinaya sequence, the ordination of slaves appears at this point (Kd 1:47.1.1). The connection is suggested by the verses of the water-carrier Puṇṇikā, who speaks of living “in fear” of her masters’ abuse and beatings.

iti91:2.5.pli: Api ca kho ‘otiṇṇamhā jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇā dukkhaparetā,
iti91:2.5.eng: Rather, because they think: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

iti91:2.6.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
iti91:2.6.eng: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

iti91:2.7.eng: That’s how this gentleman has gone forth.

iti91:2.8.pli: So ca hoti abhijjhālu kāmesu tibbasārāgo, byāpannacitto paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo, muṭṭhassati asampajāno asamāhito vibbhantacitto pākatindriyo.
iti91:2.8.eng: Yet they covet sensual pleasures; they’re infatuated, full of ill will and malicious intent. They are unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.

iti91:2.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, chavālātaṃ ubhatopadittaṃ majjhe gūthagataṃ neva gāme kaṭṭhatthaṃ pharati na araññe;
iti91:2.9.eng: Suppose there was a firebrand for lighting a funeral pyre, burning at both ends, and smeared with dung in the middle. It couldn’t be used as timber either in the village or the wilderness.

iti91:2.10.pli: tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi gihibhogā parihīno sāmaññatthañca na paripūretī”ti.
iti91:2.10.eng: I say that individual is just like this. They’ve missed out on the pleasures of the lay life, and haven’t fulfilled the goal of the ascetic life.”

iti91:3.1.eng: “They’ve left behind the pleasures of the lay life,

iti91:3.2.eng: and miss out on the goal of the ascetic life.

iti91:3.3.eng: Ruining it, they throw it away,

iti91:3.4.eng: and perish like a funeral firebrand.

iti91:4.1.eng: Many who wear a scrap of ocher cloth

iti91:4.3.eng: Being wicked, they are reborn in hell

iti91:5.1.eng: It’d be better for the immoral and unrestrained

iti91:5.4.eng: than to eat the nation’s alms.”

iti91:6.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti91:6.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti92:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti92:2.1.pli: “Saṅghāṭikaṇṇe cepi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gahetvā piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho assa pāde pādaṃ nikkhipanto,
iti92:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a mendicant were to hold the corner of my cloak and follow behind me step by step.

iti92:2.2.pli: so ca hoti abhijjhālu kāmesu tibbasārāgo byāpannacitto paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo muṭṭhassati asampajāno asamāhito vibbhantacitto pākatindriyo;
iti92:2.2.eng: Yet they covet sensual pleasures; they’re infatuated, full of ill will and malicious intent. They are unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.

iti92:2.3.pli: atha kho so ārakāva mayhaṃ, ahañca tassa.
iti92:2.3.eng: Then they are far from me, and I from them.

iti92:2.5.pli: Dhammañhi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na passati.
iti92:2.5.eng: Because that mendicant does not see the teaching.

iti92:2.6.eng: Not seeing the teaching, they do not see me.

iti92:3.1.pli: Yojanasate cepi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vihareyya.
iti92:3.1.eng: Suppose a mendicant were to live a hundred leagues away.

iti92:3.2.pli: So ca hoti anabhijjhālu kāmesu na tibbasārāgo abyāpannacitto apaduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo upaṭṭhitassati sampajāno samāhito ekaggacitto saṃvutindriyo;
iti92:3.2.eng: Yet they do not covet sensual pleasures; they’re not infatuated, or full of ill will and malicious intent. They have established mindfulness, situational awareness and immersion, with unified mind and restrained faculties.

iti92:3.3.pli: atha kho so santikeva mayhaṃ, ahañca tassa.
iti92:3.3.eng: Then they are close to me, and I to them.

iti92:3.5.eng: Because that mendicant sees the teaching.

iti92:3.6.eng: Seeing the teaching, they see me.”

iti92:4.3.eng: yet see how distant they are—

iti92:5.1.eng: An astute person who has understood

iti92:5.4.eng: like a lake unstirred by the wind.

iti92:7.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti93:3.3.eng: while, fallen in the fire of hate,

iti93:4.1.eng: and, bewildered by the fire of delusion,

iti93:4.2.eng: they miss the teaching of the noble ones.

iti93:5.1.eng: They fill the ranks of hell,

iti93:6.1.eng: But as to those committed day and night

iti93:6.2.eng: to the teaching of the Buddha:

iti93:6.3.eng: they extinguish the fire of greed,

iti93:7.2.eng: extinguish the fire of hate with love;

iti93:7.3.eng: and the fire of delusion with the wisdom

iti93:9.1.eng: Seers of the noble truths, knowledge masters,

iti93:9.3.eng: directly know the ending of rebirth,

iti93:9.4.eng: they come not back to future lives.”

iti94:2.1.pli: “Tathā tathā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu upaparikkheyya yathā yathāssa upaparikkhato bahiddhā cassa viññāṇaṃ avikkhittaṃ avisaṭaṃ ajjhattaṃ asaṇṭhitaṃ anupādāya na paritasseyya.
iti94:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant should examine in any such a way that their consciousness is neither scattered and diffused externally nor stuck internally, and they are not anxious because of grasping.

iti94:2.2.pli: Bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṃ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotī”ti.
iti94:2.2.eng: When this is the case and they are no longer anxious, there is for them no coming to be of the origin of suffering—of rebirth, old age, and death in the future.”

iti94:3.1.eng: “For one who has given up seven chains,

iti94:3.2.eng: a mendicant who has cut the cord,

iti94:3.4.eng: there’ll be no more no more future lives for them.”

iti94:4.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti94:4.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti95:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three ways of being provided with sensual pleasures.
iti95:2.1.comm: The prose phrasing in this sutta is obscure, so I have drawn out the meaning somewhat. According to the commentary, the first category refers to humans and certain devas.

iti95:2.3.eng: Some sensual pleasures are simply present; some are for those who love to create; and some are for those who control what is created by others.

iti95:2.4.eng: These are the three ways of being provided with sensual pleasures.”

iti95:3.2.eng: gods who control what is imagined by others,

iti95:3.4.eng: and others who indulge in sensual pleasures—

iti95:3.5.eng: They go from this state to another,

iti95:4.2.eng: in sensual indulgence, an astute person

iti95:5.1.eng: Having cut the stream so hard to pass,

iti95:5.2.eng: that’s tied to pleasant seeming things,

iti95:6.1.eng: Seers of the noble truths, knowledge masters,

iti95:6.3.eng: directly know the ending of rebirth,

iti95:6.4.eng: they come not back to future lives.”

iti95:7.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti95:7.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti96:2.1.pli: “Kāmayogayutto, bhikkhave, bhavayogayutto āgāmī hoti āgantā itthattaṃ.
iti96:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, one yoked to both sensual pleasures and rebirth is a returner, who comes back to this place.

iti96:2.2.pli: Kāmayogavisaṃyutto, bhikkhave, bhavayogayutto anāgāmī hoti anāgantā itthattaṃ.
iti96:2.2.eng: One unyoked from sensual pleasures but still yoked to rebirth is a non-returner, who comes not back to this place.

iti96:2.3.pli: Kāmayogavisaṃyutto, bhikkhave, bhavayogavisaṃyutto arahā hoti, khīṇāsavo”ti.
iti96:2.3.eng: One unyoked from both sensual pleasures and rebirth is a perfected one, who has ended defilements.”

iti96:3.2.eng: and the desire to be reborn in a future life;

iti96:4.1.eng: Those who’ve given up sensual pleasures

iti96:4.2.eng: without attaining the end of defilements,

iti96:4.3.eng: and are still yoked to being reborn,

iti96:5.1.eng: Those who have cut off doubt,

iti96:5.2.eng: and ended conceit and future lives,

iti96:5.3.eng: they’re the ones in this world <j>who’ve truly crossed over,

iti96:5.4.eng: having reached the ending of defilements.”

iti96:6.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti96:6.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti97:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti97:2.1.pli: “Kalyāṇasīlo, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇadhammo kalyāṇapañño imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ‘kevalī vusitavā uttamapuriso’ti vuccati—
iti97:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, in this teaching and training a mendicant of good morals, good practice, and good wisdom is called consummate, accomplished, a supreme person.
iti97:2.1.comm: Normally kalyāṇadhamma means “good character”, but here it refers to the development of meditation.

iti97:3.1.eng: And how does a mendicant have good morals?

iti97:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati, ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
iti97:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

iti97:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇasīlo hoti.
iti97:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has good morals.

iti97:3.4.eng: Such is one of good morality.

iti97:4.1.eng: And how does one have good practice?

iti97:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sattannaṃ bodhipakkhiyānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhāvanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
iti97:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates pursuing the development of the seven qualities that lead to awakening.

iti97:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇadhammo hoti.
iti97:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has good practice.

iti97:4.4.eng: Such is one of good morality and good practice.

iti97:5.1.eng: And how does one have good wisdom?

iti97:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
iti97:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

iti97:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇapañño hoti.
iti97:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has good wisdom;

iti97:6.1.pli: Iti kalyāṇasīlo kalyāṇadhammo kalyāṇapañño imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ‘kevalī vusitavā uttamapuriso’ti vuccatī”ti.
iti97:6.1.eng: Such is one of good morals, good practice, and good wisdom, who in this teaching and training is called consummate, accomplished, a supreme person.”

iti97:7.3.eng: is said to be one of good morals,

iti97:8.1.eng: Who has well developed the seven

iti97:8.3.eng: is said to be one good practice,

iti97:9.2.eng: the end of suffering in this life

iti97:9.3.eng: is said to be one good wisdom,

iti97:10.1.eng: One accomplished in these three things,

iti97:10.3.eng: unattached to anything in the world,

iti97:10.4.eng: has given up everything, they say.”

iti97:11.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti97:11.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti98:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti98:2.2.eng: A gift of things of the flesh and a gift of the teaching.

iti98:2.3.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ dānānaṃ yadidaṃ dhammadānaṃ.
iti98:2.3.eng: The better of these two gifts is the gift of the teaching.

iti98:3.1.eng: There are these two kinds of sharing.

iti98:3.2.eng: Sharing things of the flesh and sharing the teaching.

iti98:3.3.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ saṃvibhāgānaṃ yadidaṃ dhammasaṃvibhāgo.
iti98:3.3.eng: The better of these two kinds of sharing is sharing the teaching.

iti98:4.1.eng: There are these two kinds of support.

iti98:4.2.eng: Support in things of the flesh and support in the teaching.

iti98:4.3.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ anuggahānaṃ yadidaṃ dhammānuggaho”ti.
iti98:4.3.eng: The better of these two kinds of support is support in the teaching.”

iti98:5.1.eng: “It is said to be the supreme, ultimate gift,

iti98:5.2.eng: and the sharing praised by the Buddha;

iti98:5.3.eng: what wise and sensible person, <j>confident in the best of fields,

iti98:5.4.pli: Viññū pajānaṃ ko na yajetha kāle.
iti98:5.4.eng: would not sow a such timely gift?

iti98:6.1.eng: For those who are diligent <j>in the dispensation of the Holy One,

iti98:6.2.eng: both those who speak and those who listen,

iti98:6.3.eng: confident in the dispensation of the Holy One,

iti98:6.4.eng: such a gift purifies the highest goal.”

iti98:7.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti98:7.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti99:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti99:2.1.pli: “Dhammenāhaṃ, bhikkhave, tevijjaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ paññāpemi, nāññaṃ lapitalāpanamattena.
iti99:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I define a brahmin in terms of the teaching as one who is master of the three knowledges, not the other who merely repeats what they are told.

iti99:3.1.pli: Kathañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammena tevijjaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ paññāpemi, nāññaṃ lapitalāpanamattena?

iti99:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ. Tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
iti99:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

iti99:3.3.pli: Ayamassa paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā hoti, avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā, tamo vihato, āloko uppanno, yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
iti99:3.3.eng: This is the first knowledge they achieved. Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

iti99:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
iti99:4.1.eng: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, a mendicant sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

iti99:4.2.pli: Ayamassa dutiyā vijjā adhigatā hoti, avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā, tamo vihato, āloko uppanno, yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
iti99:4.2.eng: This is the second knowledge they achieved. Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

iti99:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
iti99:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

iti99:5.2.pli: Ayamassa tatiyā vijjā adhigatā hoti, avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā, tamo vihato, āloko uppanno, yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
iti99:5.2.eng: This is the third knowledge which they achieved. Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

iti99:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammena tevijjaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ paññāpemi, nāññaṃ lapitalāpanamattenā”ti.
iti99:5.3.eng: That’s how I define a brahmin in terms of the teaching as one who is master of the three knowledges, not the other who merely repeats what they are told.”

iti99:6.2.eng: sees heaven and places of loss,

iti99:6.3.eng: and has attained the end of rebirth,

iti99:6.4.eng: is a sage of perfect insight.

iti99:7.2.eng: a brahmin is a master of the three knowledges.

iti99:7.3.eng: That’s who I call a three-knowledge master,

iti99:7.4.eng: and not the other <j>who repeats what they are told.”

iti99:8.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti99:8.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
